clinical_study.brief_title: A Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and Yoga Program for Trauma Symptoms
clinical_study.official_title: A Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and Yoga Program for Trauma Symptoms

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the proposed study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and yoga program for improving posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms and sleep quality in people who have experienced a traumatic event and are reporting trauma symptoms.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of the proposed study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and yoga program for improving posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms and sleep quality in people who have experienced a traumatic event and are reporting trauma symptoms. The total length of the program will be 8 weeks. The sessions will be held 3 hours per week with 1.5 hours of group cognitive behavioral therapy and 1.5 hours of yoga. Changes in PTSD symptoms and sleep quality will be measured at baseline, immediately following the program, and at 2 month follow-up.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in Posttraumatic Stress Symptoms will be measured using the PTSD Checklist for the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5 (DSM-5) (PCL-5)
primary_outcome.description: Changes in Posttraumatic Stress Symptoms will be measured using the PTSD Checklist for the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5 (DSM-5) (PCL-5)

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in Sleep Quality will be measured using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI)
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in Sleep Quality will be measured using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI)

intervention.description: Group Cognitive Behavioral Therapy Treatment and Yoga Program

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- clinically diagnosed posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) or subthreshold PTSD symptoms
Exclusion Criteria:
- current uncontrolled psychotic or bipolar disorder, significant cognitive impairment, substance dependence, non-English speaking, or a significant medical condition that would interfere with participation in the yoga portion of the program
